p.s: Romeo's and Juliet's love for eachother is not any ordinary love.
Their first interaction lead to a kiss, although Juliet has Paris as a date and leda to both of them comitting the love for eachother.

While Juliet experiences her first love as a very intense one, without as she says not yet drunk a hundred words ofOf that tongue's utterance meaning (l. 58) that she fell in love with Romeo without having spoken much with him.
This is not only very special, as a phenomenon itself, but also because it contradicts two key aspects.
Juliet is not only part of the Capulets, the rivaling family of the Montagues and Romeo as their son, but she also is supposed to marry Paris, the rich governor's son.
Her love towards Romeo, which contradicts both original interests, Paris and Rosaline, is shared by her love.
Romeo is ready to ignore the family feud for their love's sake Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?(l. 60) Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike(l. 61), as is Juliet.
Romeo then says that love leads to attempts, which are dangerous and boundaries cannot stop true love: For stony limits cannot hold love out, Andand what love can do that dares love attempt(l. 67).

Romeo talks about two things representative for boundaries, firstly he talks about the wall as a boundary, that he has had to climb, and metaphorically he speaks about the family feud against their families as a confining boundary.

Romeo is also raving to JulietsJuliet's and using very Christian language, such as fair saint(l. 61), which shows that he sees her and his love as something godly and very special, which, in his eyes, is a reason to rebel against their families and their feud And I am proof against their enmity(l. 73).
He even goes further and accepts the risk of death for her love (ll. 78 + 83).
Then in line 98 Juliet accepts to rebel against all conventions if Romeo swears that his love is real.
Even Juliet recognises her irrationality (l. 98) I am too fond even though she is, compared to Romeo; not as emotional but rather precautious.
Although Romeo swears his real love, Shakespeare intentionally put the act about Romeo being sad about Rosaline before this act.
It is questionable if Romeo is really lovingreally loves Juliet, as he claims, or if he experiences only lust as in the prior indicdent regarding Rosaline.
